title: 115_s2018
content: The "American Family Act of 2017" establishes a fully refundable Child Tax Credit by eliminating the existing credit and inserting a new section 36C in the Internal Revenue Code. The "American Family Act of 2017" introduces a new Child Tax Credit, allowing a credit for qualifying children based on their age and deduction amount. The credit is subject to limitations based on income. The "American Family Act of 2017" introduces a new Child Tax Credit, subject to income limitations. The credit amount is reduced based on the taxpayer's modified adjusted gross income exceeding certain threshold amounts. The "American Family Act of 2017" introduces a new Child Tax Credit, subject to income limitations. The credit amount is reduced based on the taxpayer's modified adjusted gross income exceeding specific threshold amounts: $110,000 for joint returns, $75,000 for individuals not married, and $55,000 for married individuals filing separately. Marital status is determined under section 7703. The applicable amount is calculated as the quotient of the credit allowable under certain conditions. The Child Tax Credit under the "American Family Act of 2017" is based on income limitations and marital status determined under section 7703. The applicable amount is calculated as the quotient of the credit allowable under specific conditions. A qualifying child is defined as one who has not reached 19 years of age. The Child Tax Credit is based on income limitations and marital status. A qualifying child is defined as one under 19 years of age, with exceptions for non-citizens. There is an inflation adjustment for the $3,000 amount after 2017. Inflation adjustment for the $3,000 amount in the Child Tax Credit after 2017 includes a cost of living adjustment based on the calendar year. Identification requirements for qualifying children are also specified. The Child Tax Credit amount is adjusted for inflation based on the calendar year. Taxpayers must provide the name and taxpayer identification number of qualifying children on their tax return to claim the credit. The Child Tax Credit requires taxpayers to provide the name and taxpayer identification number of qualifying children on their tax return. The credit is not allowed if the taxpayer's identification number was issued after the due date for filing the return. Additionally, the credit is not allowable for a taxable year covering less than 12 months, except in cases of a taxpayer's death. No credit is allowed for taxpayers who improperly claimed the credit in a prior year due to fraudulent or reckless claims. No credit is allowed under this section for a taxable year covering less than 12 months, except in cases of a taxpayer's death. Taxpayers who improperly claimed the credit in a prior year due to fraudulent or reckless claims will not be allowed the credit for a specified disallowance period. Taxpayers who fraudulently or recklessly claimed the credit will be denied the credit for a specified disallowance period, which is 10 years for fraud and 2 years for reckless or intentional disregard of rules. Taxpayers denied credit for reckless disregard of rules must provide information to demonstrate eligibility for the credit in subsequent years. The credit allowed for a taxable year will be reduced by any advance payments received for that year. The credit allowed for a taxable year will be reduced by any advance payments received for that year, and excess advance payments will result in an increase in the tax imposed for that year. "SEC. 7527A. ADVANCE PAYMENT OF CHILD TAX CREDIT." The Secretary will establish a program for monthly advance payments of the child tax credit within a year of enactment. Payments will be limited to prevent exceeding the total credit amount for each taxpayer. The program for monthly advance payments of the child tax credit limits payments to ensure they do not exceed the total credit amount for each taxpayer. The payments made to any taxpayer during the taxable year must not exceed the difference between the amount determined under section 36C and the estimated tax imposed by subtitle A, reduced by certain credits. The program for monthly advance payments of the child tax credit limits payments to ensure they do not exceed the total credit amount for each taxpayer, with exceptions noted in section 36C. Conforming amendments are made to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The child tax credit program limits monthly advance payments to prevent exceeding the total credit amount for each taxpayer, with exceptions in section 36C. Amendments are made to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 regarding the advance payment of child tax credit, including changes to sections 45R(f)(3), 152(f)(6)(B)(ii), and 501(c). Amendments to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 include changes to various sections such as 152(f)(6)(B)(ii), 501(c), 6211(b)(4)(A), 6213(g)(2), and 1324(b) to update references from "section 24" to "section 36C". Amendments to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 update references from "section 24" to "section 36C" in various sections. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2016.
